text.p: Write a Python function f that takes an input string s and returns a dictionary that maps each character that occurs in s to the number of times it occurs in s. For example, if s = 'a*c3Ca*' the function f should return the dictionary: {'a': 2, '*': 2, 'c': 1, '3': 1, 'C': 1}. Note that the dictionary keys are case sensitive.
text.pre: def f(s): ''' Assumes: s is a string Effects: returns a dict that maps each character that occurs in s to the number of times it occurs in s For example, f('a*c3Ca*') returns the dict {'a': 2, '*': 2, 'c': 1, '3': 1, 'C': 1} ''' # Your code here

codeparam.initial_display: def f(s): ''' Assumes: s is a string Effects: returns a dict that maps each character that occurs in s to the number of times it occurs in s For example, f('a*c3Ca*') returns the dict {'a': 2, '*': 2, 'c': 1, '3': 1, 'C': 1} ''' # Your code here

problem.p: Note: An L379 or L397 error: means that your code has an infinite loop for some test case. You will receive a zero for this problem if your code has an infinite loop.

Note on Score Shown: Your code will ultimately be run on our test cases. Getting "Correct"/green check during the exam does not mean you will get full points. The test cases here ensure you do not have a copy/paste error from your IDE.
